selected_quotes: Paper by HCEO Member Kimberly Noble: Socioeconomic Status and Structural Brain Development
Socioeconomic status and structural brain development: Natalie H Brito and Kimberly G Noble #neuroscience
Socioeconomic status and structural brain development #psychology #neuroscience #sociology #anthropology
Great review article on #SocioeconomicStatus and structural #brain development by Brito
@npr_ed does this mean that low ses children will also have greater rights?

citation.abstract: Recent advances in neuroimaging methods have made accessible new ways of disentangling the complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors that influence structural brain development. In recent years, research investigating associations between socioeconomic status (SES) and brain development have found significant links between SES and changes in brain structure, especially in areas related to memory, executive control, and emotion. This review focuses on studies examining links between structural brain development and SES disparities of the magnitude typically found in developing countries. We highlight how highly correlated measures of SES are differentially related to structural changes within the brain.
citation.title: Socioeconomic status and structural brain development.
